docs.lead_paragraph: THE best time to start a business is when you have a job, as illustrated by the experience of Roy R. Westmoreland, a former human resources training consultant at International Business Machines. ''In the spring of 1993 I.B.M. made me a one-time buy-out offer that was too good to pass up,'' Mr. Westmoreland said. ''I would get a year's salary plus retirement benefits that were being frozen at the 30-year mark. I was 54 and had been with I.B.M. for 32 years. It was a very good offer and although I liked what I was doing, I saw the handwriting on the wall and decided to accept early retirement.''

headline.main: Buyout Package Brings a New Business

docs.abstract: Profile of and interview with former IBM executive Roy R Westmoreland, who took early retirement in 1993 and opened ASAP Messenger, small package-delivery service in Thornwood, NY; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Colfax boys know better than to dip their toes in Acid Brook. Never mind that their father splashed in the stream as a child, even drinking from it on steamy summer days. It is off limits now, just like the abandoned explosives plant owned by E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, which lies just beyond their yard. ''Everything around here is contaminated, from what I hear,'' said Steve Colfax, the father of the two boys. ''I'm not taking any chances,'' he said, peering at the Du Pont property from behind his screen door.

headline.main: Fear and Heartache in Polluted Village

docs.abstract: du Pont's offer of $38.5 million to settle lawsuit over pollution of Acid Brook in Pompton Lakes, New Jersey, is cold comfort to families who have lived with fear and health consequences for years; 1983 lawsuit charged company with dumping lead, mercury and other hazardous substances into brook that runs from explosives plant, now closed, through town; map; Steve Colfax, who had moved away for time before returning to rent home next to site, is bitter at not being asked to join suit; most awards range from $70,000 to $80,000 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: As the securities, banking, insurance and money management industries continue their rapid consolidation, some of the biggest names in finance are on the prowl for acquisitions on Wall Street -- or have recently made the plunge. The main decision they all face is which firm will give them the biggest lift as they seek to build a global financial business. Those now scouting the field include the ING Group of the Netherlands, Societe Generale of France, Chase Manhattan and J. P. Morgan.

headline.main: In Financial Arena, Merger Is the Game

docs.lead_paragraph: Michael Molloy, a 29-year-old advertising salesman from Allentown, Pa., is a gravely ill patient at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center on Manhattan's Upper East Side. Mr. Molloy was diagnosed with melanoma in August 1995. The disease has spread relentlessly since then, advancing to his lungs and most recently to his brain. The situation is desperate. With standard treatment, Mr. Molloy might survive another four or five months. With luck, maybe until Christmas. There is, however, a potential alternative. The most immediate threat to Mr. Molloy are the tumors in his brain. Dr. Jonathan Finlay, director of the hospital's pediatric brain tumor program and a specialist in brain tumors in children and adults, has had some success over the past decade with an extremely aggressive form of chemotherapy.
docs.abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column criticizes Principal Financial Group for refusing to pay for proposed treatment for Michael Molloy, gravely ill cancer patient at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, because health insurance company said treatment was experimental (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's unemployment rate rose two-tenths of a percentage point in June, to 5 percent, easing the tightest labor market in a quarter century, Government figures showed today. A moderate 217,000 jobs were added to payrolls. While the figures showed a blip up in the jobless rate after trending downward for many months and a slowdown in the recent rapid rate of job creation, they were just what the White House and Wall Street wanted. Financial markets reveled in the news because it suggested that the economy was still growing solidly but no longer at the breakneck pace of earlier in the year that threatened to fan fears of inflation. Interest rates tumbled by about one-eighth of a percentage point and stocks, as gauged by the Dow Jones industrial average, soared more than 100 points to another record in shortened pre-holiday trading. $(Page D1.$)
docs.abstract: Nation's unemployment rate rises two-tenths of percentage point in June, to 5 percent, easing tightest labor market in quarter century; Government figures show moderate 217,000 jobs were added to payrolls; chief dark spot in job picture is fact that ranks of unemployed grew by 302,000, more than offsetting May's improvement; analysts feel that despite rise in unemployment rate, job market remains in healthy shape; White House and Wall Street hail figures, which suggest economy is still growing solidly but no longer at breakneck pace of earlier in year that threatened to fan fears of inflation; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors are investigating charges that doctors at Kings County Hospital Center routinely defrauded the city by diverting insured patients from the public hospital to the state-run University Hospital of Brooklyn across the street, where the doctors could make more money doing the same procedures, the president of the city's public hospitals agency said yesterday. The president, Dr. Luis Marcos, said an investigation by the Inspector General of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation concluded that residents in training at Kings County were intimidated by senior doctors into transferring insured patients to University Hospital of Brooklyn, better known as Downstate. Senior doctors who work at both hospitals are paid a fixed salary for their work at Kings County; their income at University Hospital increases with the volume of their services there.

headline.main: Patient-Shifting Practices At Center Are Scrutinized

docs.abstract: Federal prosecutors investigate charges that doctors at Kings County Medical Center have routinely diverted insured patients from New York City-owned hospital to affiliated University Hospital across the street, where they could earn more for same procedures; senior physicians allegedly intimidated residents into transferring patients to state-run hospital where doctors are paid by number of patients, rather than by fixed salary; probe centers on orthopedic surgery and Dr Paul Tornetta, chief of fracture service; Health and Hospitals head Dr Luis Marcos gives priority to ending transfer practice, which costs city money (S)
docs.snippet: Federal prosecutors are investigating charges that doctors at Kings County Hospital Center routinely defrauded the city by diverting insured patients from the public hospital to the state-run University Hospital of Brooklyn across the street, where...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Hong Kong Leader Explains Life Under Chinese Rule Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa of Hong Kong sought to explain the Chinese blueprint for the former colony to its residents. And in what may be the first test of China's pledge that Hong Kong would be allowed its own distinct form of government, the police allowed a demonstration by a group, the Hong Kong Alliance, that China has branded subversive. A1 President Jiang Zemin of China called on Taiwan to take ''concrete steps'' to join the mainland under the ''one country, two systems'' formula promised for Hong Kong. A11

docs.lead_paragraph: Estimates by the Congressional Budget Office suggest that health care bills passed last week by the House and the Senate would fall far short of the goal of guaranteeing coverage for half of the nation's 10 million uninsured children. Lawmakers of both parties said they were surprised and dismayed by the preliminary estimates, which indicated that fewer than 1.5 million uninsured children would gain coverage. The lawmakers insisted that more children would benefit from the legislation.

headline.main: HEALTH CARE BILLS DON'T MEET GOALS, BUDGET AIDES SAY

docs.abstract: Congressional Budget Office says health care bills recently passed by House and Senate will fall far short of goal of guaranteeing coverage for half of nation's 10 million uninsured children; lawmakers are surprised and dismayed by CBO's preliminary estimates, which indicate that fewer than 1.5 million uninsured children will gain coverage; CBO says that large numbers of children expected to receive aid under two bills--perhaps 40 percent--already have insurance coverage from other sources, and net increase in children with insurance will be smaller than members of Congress had assumed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IF an insurance company initially refuses to pay for medically indicated treatment, is it ethical for a primary care doctor to lie to get the coverage for a patient? When this question was posed in a survey to 167 internists around the country, 45 percent said yes. Dr. Victor G. Freeman, a primary care research fellow at Georgetown University Medical Center who did the survey, found that the more potentially lifesaving the coverage, the stronger the support for lying.
docs.abstract: Survey of 167 internists nationwide shows 45 percent would lie if insurance company initially refused to pay for medically indicated treatment; found more potentially lifesaving the coverage, stronger was support for lying (S)
